Description: The head of a hollow terracotta horse, broken from a figure. A suspension-hole is pierced through the neck. Two-piece mould. Pink Aswan kaolinite ware. White/yellow slip overall. Mane, eyes, ears and harness are in fired-on black ceramic colour; orange-red colour on front of head, across throat and down chest.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Elephantine?: most of the Registration Numbers leading up to this one were purchased there, and the mark 'E' may point to this place. Late Roman, sixth or seventh century AD. Comparanda: Near: Adams 2000: 93, fig. 31c, pl. 20d:3, from Meinarti in Nubia, context between about late fifth and mid-seventh century AD; Bonham and Brooks' 'Sale Catalogue', 8 November 2001: lot 655; Bonham's 'Sale Catalogue', 16 May 2002: lot 703; Boutantin 2004: 9, fig. 4, from Narmouthis, dated fifth to sixth century AD; Mond and Myers 1940: pls xxvi:P 17 and lxx:20, from Armant. Bibliog: Boutantin 2004: 4, no. 7, dated fifth to sixth century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3757)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
